awd_titl_txt: SG: Ecological insights from range-expanding populations
awd_abstract_narration:
As the atmosphere and oceans warm, plants and animals are expanding their geographic distributions. For instance, the fiddler crab recently expanded its range north of its historic limit of Cape Cod, Massachusetts. While scientists have documented the range expansion of thousands of species, a big question remains: What is the impact of these organisms on the new habitats they occupy in their expanded ranges? Fiddler crabs live in salt marshes, which are economically important ecosystems that fuel fisheries and tourism. This research will focus on the impact that fiddler crabs will have on salt marshes in the newly expanded range (i.e., north of Cape Cod). Findings from this project will be made available to the public. Middle-school teachers and students in addition to undergraduate and graduate students will be directly involved in this research. 

The documented northern expansion of fiddler crabs (Uca pugnax) is an exceptional opportunity to test the effects of climate-driven species introductions on ecosystem functioning. In its native range, U. pugnax influences a range of marsh functioning including primary production, nutrient cycling, and food-webs. In terms of body size, fiddler crabs follow Bergmann's Rule (a positive relationship between body size and latitude) with individuals in Massachusetts being almost twice as large as those in Georgia. This biogeographic pattern may inform the relative effect of individual populations on ecosystem function in the context of climate change. The following hypotheses will be tested in this study: (1.) Fiddler crabs in the expanded-range populations (e.g., Massachusetts) will have larger per-capita effects on marsh functioning than those in the historic-range populations (e.g., Georgia) because of their larger size. (2.) At the landscape-scale, range-expanded crabs will have minor effects on marsh functioning relative to historic crabs because these populations are 10x smaller than historic-range populations. These hypotheses will be tested using a combination of field experiments and observational studies along a latitudinal gradient (Georgia, Virginia, Massachusetts) on a suite of ecosystem processes (e.g., primary production, decomposition, benthic animal diversity, plant stoichiometry). In addition, the targeted hypothesis that fiddler crab body size is correlated with ecosystem impacts will be tested in a mesocosm study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: College of William & Mary Virginia Institute of Marine Science

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
The world’s oceans are warming. As a result, some marine species are shifting or expanding their ranges. These species are climate migrants. In this research, PI Johnson and his team asked, what happens to ecosystems when climate migrants arrive? Specifically, he looked at the influence of the mud fiddler crab, Minuca pugnax (formerly Uca pugnax), on saltmarsh grasses and soils in their expanded range.

First, the team asked if crab density (number per m2) and the size of the crab influenced its effect on the marsh. Based on a mesocosm study conducted in Virginia – the crab’s historical range, they found that only the largest crabs at highest densities increased aboveground biomass of the marsh grass Spartina alterniflora by 30%. All other treatments were ineffective.  

Next the team looked at the effect of fiddler crabs in the expanded range, specifically the Plum Island Ecosystem Long-Term Ecological Research site (northeast Massachusetts). There they found that fiddler crabs reduced aboveground and belowground biomass of the marsh grass, Spartina alterniflora (Martínez-Soto & Johnson 2023, Ecology). For almost half a century, the paradigm was that fiddler crabs enhance aboveground biomass of Spartina. Fiddler crabs also reduced benthic microalgae in their expanded range (Johnson et al. 2020, J. Crustacean Biology). Their densities are accelerating in the expanded range and are now 20x higher than initially (Martínez-Soto & Johnson 2020, J. Crustacean Biology). Fiddler crabs have fewer parasites in their expanded than historical range (Johnson et al. 2020, Marine Ecology Progress Series). Their findings indicate that the ecological roles of climate migrants may differ between their historical and expanded ranges.

This project trained graduate students, K. Martínez-Soto, E. Goetz, & S. Wittyngham, a middle-school teacher (J. Reynolds), a lab technician (M. Pant) and an undergraduate (V. Acosta Rodriguez). This research was the basis of a K12 lesson plan developed with the Virginia Scientists & Educators Alliance.


Last Modified: 03/18/2024
Modified by: David S Johnson
